thread.title: MHS netters set sights on regional, 3-2-1A state berths this weekend
thread.title_full: MHS netters set sights on regional, 3-2-1A state berths this weekend

title: MHS netters set sights on regional, 3-2-1A state berths this weekend
text: Untitled Document MHS netters set sights on regional, 3-2-1A state berths this weekend Madison Nieberding, Marysville, returns a volley during No. 1 doubles Saturday in Concordia. Photo by Julie Perry Published: Thursday, October 8, 2015 10:29 PM CDT Every point matters and Marysville girls’ tennis team learned that Saturday during the North Central Kansas League tournament at Concordia.More importantly though is that the Bulldogs approach the two-day 3-2-1A regional at Harmon Park in Prairie Village, Kan., focused on every point, because this is a state qualifier. Maranatha Christian Academy in Shawnee, Kan., is the tournament hosts. The regional, which starts Friday after a 10 a.m. coaches meeting, will have teams from Wabaunsee, Leavenworth-Immaculata, Neodesha, Perry-Lecompton, Pittsburg-St. Mary’s Colgan, Kansas City Christian, Sabetha and the hosts.The top six singles and top six doubles teams will advance to the Oct. 16-17 state tournament also at Harmon Park. There will be no distinction between No. 1s and No. 2s.Marysville is coming off a second-place team finish in the NCKL tournament where the Dogs scored 35 points and placed everyone. Clay Center, which won three divisions, won its first league crown since 1996. Abilene was third with 31 points. MHS’ No. 1 doubles team of Madison Nieberding and Shelby Downard won based on percentage of wins over teams from Chapman and Abilene.All three were 4-1. Marysville lost to Chapman 8-6 in the second round of the tournament, but the Bulldogs downed Abilene in the fourth round, 8-3.Nieberding and Downard opened the tournament with an 8-2 win against Wamego, and rebounded from the loss to Chapman to win 8-4 against Clay Center. The Bulldogs closed with an 8-0 win over Concordia.At No. 2 doubles, MHS’ team of Holly Holthaus and Avery Williams was 4-1 with a third-round loss to Clay Center. The MHS pair lost 8-6 to the Tigers. In other rounds, Holthaus and Williams won 8-3 against Wamego; 7-5 in a tiebreaker for an 8-7 win over Chapman; 7-4 in a tiebreaker for an 8-7 win over Abilene; and 8-0 against Concordia.In No. 1 singles, MHS’ Rachel Frese was third after a 3-2 day. She won 8-1 over Wamego’s Anna Stratton and 8-0 over Chapman’s Abigail Channing.In the third round, Frese fell 8-6 to Clay Center’s Hannah Callan and 8-6 to Abilene’s Rachael Lillich. In the last round, Frese won 8-0 against Con’s Cameron Collins. At No. 2 singles for MHS, Megan Hill was 3-2 and third. She fell to Chapman’s Brianna Loy, 8-0, and Clay Center’s Chloe Gaug, 8-4. Hill won 8-5 over Wamego’s Jennifer Griffitt, 8-3 against Abilene’s Kylie Coup, and 8-0 over Concordia’s Jenna Fredrickson.
